para.heading: Nudity.
para.text: "Nudity" means:
the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering;
the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering over any part below the top of the nipple; or
the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state.

para.heading: Partial nudity.
para.text: "Partial nudity" means a state of dress in which opaque clothing covers no more than:
the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or buttocks;
the female breasts below the top of the nipples; and
portions of the body covered by supporting straps or devices.

para.heading: "Adult entertainment" defined.
para.text: "Adult entertainment" means live entertainment:
in which individuals appear for public view in a state of nudity or partial nudity;
that is intended to provide sexual stimulation or sexual gratification;
that is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on material that depicts, describes, or relates to:
human genitals in a discernible state of sexual stimulation or arousal; or
acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse, sodomy, or physical contact with an individual's clothed or unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or, if the individual is female, breast; or
that, applying contemporary standards, the average individual would find, taken as a whole, appeals to the prurient interest.

para.heading: Adult-entertainment business.
para.text: "Adult-entertainment business" means any cabaret, lounge, night club, modeling studio, or other establishment that offers its customers adult entertainment.

para.heading: Board.
para.text: "Board" means the Board of Liquor License Commissioners for Baltimore City.

para.heading: Board may adopt.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Board may adopt rules, regulations, and forms to carry out the provisions of this subtitle.

para.heading: Public hearing and comment.
para.text: In accordance with General Provisions Article § 4-301:
the Board must publish, for public hearing and comment, notice of all rules, regulations, and forms proposed for adoption under this subtitle; and
notice of the date, time, and location of the hearing must be published at least 15 days before the hearing.

para.heading: Effective date.
para.text: After the public hearing and comment period, the Board may adopt the final rules, regulations, and forms with an effective date of at least 15 days after the date of their adoption.

section.heading: Scope.
section.text: Nothing in this subtitle is intended to permit any activity that is otherwise prohibited by federal, state, or local law.

section.heading: License required.
section.text: A person may not own or operate any adult-entertainment business without having first obtained an adult-entertainment business license as provided in this subtitle.

para.heading: Owner and operator to apply jointly.
para.text: The owner and operator of the adult-entertainment business must apply jointly to the Board for the license.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: The application must be in the form and contain the information that the Board requires.
An application for an adult-entertainment business license must be made on or before the date of applying for the conditional use approval required under the Zoning Code.
The adult-entertainment business license may not become effective unless a conditional use has been approved and any right of appeal contesting that approval has been exhausted.

para.heading: By whom made.
para.text: The application of every owner and operator must be made as follows:
if a corporation, by its chief executive officer;
if a partnership, by its managing partner; or
if a proprietorship, by its owners.

para.heading: Information and determination.
para.text: All information required in the application about an applicant must be given with respect to the individuals making the application, and the determination of the Board must be based on the eligibility of those individuals.

section.heading: Investigation of applicants.
section.text: On receipt of the application, the Board must investigate the character and qualifications of the applicants.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: An adult-entertainment business license may not be issued to any person to own or operate an adult-entertainment business unless the applicant:
based on the considerations specified in subsection (b) of this section, is of good moral character;
is at least 18 years of age; and
within the preceding 3 years, has not been convicted of or pleaded guilty or nolo contendere in any jurisdiction to a felony involving:
moral turpitude;
controlled dangerous substances;
prostitution;
obscenity; or
any other crime that is sexual in nature.

para.heading: Required considerations.
para.text: In determining moral character, the Board must consider:
all criminal convictions of the applicant; and
the business history of the applicant.

para.heading: Posting required.
para.text: On filing an application for a license (other than a renewal license), the applicant must post the proposed location for 15 days, in accordance with the Board's rules and regulations.

para.heading: 9 or fewer objections.
para.text: If, within the 15-day posting period, the Board receives no more than 9 written objections from property owners or residents within the same election precinct as the proposed location, the adult-entertainment business license may be issued.

If, within the 15-day posting period, the Board receives 10 or more written objections from property owners or residents within the same election precinct as the proposed location, the Board must hold a hearing on the matter.
Unless the applicant agrees to a later date, the hearing must be held within 15 days after the last day of the 15-day posting period.
At the hearing, parties in interest and citizens must be given an opportunity to be heard.

para.heading: Board to decide.
para.text: The Board must notify the applicant in writing of its decision to grant or deny the license as follows:
if no hearing is held under § 1-12(c) of this subtitle, within 15 days after the last day of the 15-day posting period; and
if a hearing is held under § 1-12(c) of this subtitle, within 15 days after conclusion of the hearing.
Any denial of an adult-entertainment business license must be based solely on the qualifications set forth in § 1-11 of this subtitle.
The notice of a denial must:
specify the reasons for the denial; and
notify the applicant of the opportunity to request a hearing under § 1-30 of this subtitle.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Each adult-entertainment business license expires annually on June 30 and is renewable as provided in this section.
To renew an adult-entertainment business license, the licensee must apply no less than 30 days nor more than 60 days before the license expires.
The renewal application must be in the form and contain the information that the Board requires.

para.heading: Approval.
para.text: On filing the renewal application and payment of the renewal fee, the Board may approve the application, except as provided in subsection (d) of this section.

If, before the end of the renewal period, 10 or more written objections from property owners or residents within the same election precinct as the licensed premises are filed with the Board, the Board must hold a public hearing on the proposed renewal.
Parties in interest and citizens must be given an opportunity to be heard.
Any denial of a renewal license must be based solely on the standards set forth in § 1-28 of this subtitle.

para.heading: Annual fee.
para.text: The annual license fee is $1,000 for each adult-entertainment business, payable on or before June 30 of each year.

para.heading: Initial fee.
para.text: The license fee for less than a full initial year is prorated quarterly.

section.heading: Waiting period after denial.
section.text: If the Board denies an adult-entertainment business license or renewal license, the applicant may not reapply for at least 9 months from the date of the Board's final decision or, if that decision was appealed, from the date of the final court decision.

section.heading: Transfer of license.
section.text: An adult-entertainment business license is not transferable to a new owner or operator without a new application to the Board.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no live adult entertainment may be conducted between the hours of 2 a.m. and noon.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: If the State changes the closing time for holders of alcoholic beverage licensees, that closing time will apply to adult-entertainment businesses.

para.heading: Exterior entrance doors.
para.text: Exterior entrance doors:
must be kept closed so that adult entertainment activities are not visible from the exterior of the building; and
may be opened only:
to permit entry and exit; or
for cleaning or ventilation during nonoperational hours.

para.heading: Entertainment not to be visible from exterior.
para.text: The conduct of adult entertainment may not be visible at any time from the exterior of the premises in which it is conducted.

para.heading: Enclosed vestibule or lobby.
para.text: The premises of each adult-entertainment business must have a vestibule or lobby enclosed by immobile walls and consisting of a passage, hall, or room between the outer door facing the street and the part of the premises where the adult entertainment is conducted.

section.heading: "Barking".
section.text: Any attempt to urge, invite, or entice people to enter the premises of an adult-entertainment business is prohibited anywhere within 50 feet of the premises.

section.heading: Owner, etc., to prevent nuisance.
section.text: Every owner, operator, and manager of an adult-entertainment business must exercise proper care and control to prevent the business or its operations from becoming or creating a public nuisance, whether by the generation of noise, the blocking of public ways, or otherwise.

section.heading: License to be posted.
section.text: The person to whom an adult-entertainment business license is issued must display it in the lobby, vestibule, or other prominent place on the premises.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Board may deny, suspend, or revoke an adult-entertainment business license or renewal license for any of the following causes:
failing to pay the applicable license fee on or before the due date;
making any material false statement in any application for an initial or renewal license;
lack of accessibility for fire and police protection;
failing to comply with any provision of the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article, Health Code Article, or Zoning Code Article;
failing to comply with any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle; or
failing to comply with any provision of any other local, state, or federal law that affects or relates to the operation of the adult-entertainment business.

para.heading: Offenses by owner, operator, or manager.
para.text: The Board also may deny, suspend, or revoke an adult-entertainment business license or renewal license for the violation, by any owner, operator, or manager of the adult-entertainment business, of any provision of any local, state, or federal law that involves:
the manufacture, distribution, possession, or administration of controlled dangerous substances;
prostitution, sodomy, perverted sexual practices, or a bawdy house or disorderly house; or
obscene matter or immoral practices.

para.heading: Offenses by employee, etc., or vendor.
para.text: The Board also may deny, suspend, or revoke an adult-entertainment business license or renewal license for the violation, by any employee, agent, independent contractor, or vendor of the adult-entertainment business, of any law referred to in subsection (b) of this section, if:
the offense occurred on the premises of the adult-entertainment business; and
either:
the owner, operator, or manager affirmatively or tacitly approved of the offense;
the owner, operator, or manager had actual or constructive knowledge of the offense;
the owner, operator, or manager reasonably should have known of the offense; or
the offense was a result of the owner, operator, or manager's failure to supervise.

section.heading: Fines.
section.text: For any violation that is cause for suspending or revoking a license, the Board may, instead of or in addition to suspending or revoking the license, impose a civil fine of:

para.text: for a 1st offense, not more than $500; and
for any subsequent offense, not more than $1,000.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No adult-entertainment business license or renewal license may be denied, suspended, or revoked and no fine may be imposed unless the Board gives the applicant or licensee:
at least 10 days' written notice of the intent to impose sanctions; and
an opportunity to be heard as to why sanctions should not be imposed.

para.heading: Denial of initial license.
para.text: For the proposed denial of an initial license, a hearing must be held within 30 days of a timely request, unless the applicant agrees to a later date.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: A person aggrieved by a decision of the Board under this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.
It is the desire and intent of the Mayor and City Council that any review under this section be heard and decided by the Court as expeditiously as possible.
To that end, the Board must join in any motion by the appellant for expedited review and cooperate fully with the appellant to obtain an expedited review.
The filing of a petition for judicial review does not stay the decision of the Board.
However, on motion and after hearing, the Court may grant a stay as provided in the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

section.heading: Task Force established.
section.text: There is an Adult-Entertainment Business Advisory Task Force.

section.heading: Purpose.
section.text: The purpose of the Advisory Task Force is to advise the appropriate administrative and elected officials on matters related to the conduct of adult-entertainment businesses.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Advisory Task Force consists of 9 members who serve without compensation.

para.heading: Representation.
para.text: The Mayor appoints the members of the Advisory Task Force, as follows:
2 members from a list of 4 nominees by the Citizens Planning and Housing Association;
1 member from a list of 2 nominees by the Greater Baltimore Committee;
1 member from a list of 2 nominees by the Baltimore City Chamber of Commerce;
3 members, 2 of whom must be members of the Baltimore Entertainment Center, Inc., from a list of 6 nominees by the holders of adult-entertainment business licenses;
1 member from a list of 2 nominees by the Downtown Partnership, Inc.; and
1 member, who must be a member of the Baltimore City Council, nominated by the President of the City Council.
The terms of the members are as provided in Article IV, § 6 of the City Charter.
No individual may serve more than 2 consecutive terms on the Advisory Task Force.

para.heading: Chair.
para.text: The Mayor designates the chair of the Advisory Task Force.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates, omits, neglects, or refuses to comply with, or resists the enforcement of any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues after notification constitutes a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No billiard, bagatelle, pool, manhattan, klondike, or rondo table may be erected, set up, kept, or in any respect whatever used for the purpose of gain or public entertainment within the City without a license previously obtained from the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Every license granted under this section terminates on January 1 annually.

para.heading: Fee.
para.text: For every license granted under this section, the person obtaining it shall pay to the Director of Finance for the use of the City $130 for each billiard, bagatelle, pool, manhattan, klondike, or rondo table.

section.heading: Prohibited games.
section.text: Every game or games played upon billiard tables shall be deemed and considered unlawful, and are hereby prohibited, except only the game played with 2 balls, the game played with 3 balls, the game played with 4 balls, and the game commonly called pool, such being the usual games of billiards.

section.heading: Hours.
section.text: It is unlawful for any person having a license to erect or keep a pool or billiard saloon or pool or billiard table as mentioned in § 2-2:

para.text: to allow any person or persons to play on or use any pool or billiard table between the hours of 1 a.m. and 7 a.m.; or
knowingly to allow a minor to play on or use any pool or billiard table, or play at any game in that saloon, or be on the premises, at any time.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No person may erect, set up, keep, maintain, or in any respect whatever use for amusement or entertainment within the City, any bowling saloon, bowling alley, nine- or ten-pin alley, or any other device or structure, in or upon which 1 or more pins are set up, for the purpose of casting, throwing, pushing, or rolling against the pin or pins, 1 or more balls or other missiles, without having obtained a license therefor.

para.heading: Fee.
para.text: For this license there shall be annually paid a sum computed at the rate of $40 for each separate "lane" or "alley", with a minimum license fee for any 1 location or premises to be $100 annually.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: Nothing in this section, however, shall be construed to require any bona fide religious, charitable, educational, or medical institution, operating 7 or fewer "lanes" or "alleys" to obtain a license, as long as any proceeds from the operation of these "lanes" or "alleys" are devoted to charitable purposes exclusively or in furtherance of the purposes of that institution.

section.heading: Hours.
section.text: It is unlawful for the proprietor of any bowling alley, device, or structure, or for any person who has a permit or license to erect or keep any bowling alley, device, or structure:

para.text: to allow any person to play on or use the alley, device, or structure, in any manner whatever, after 2 a.m. and before sunrise in the morning; or

to allow any minor under 14 years of age to play on or use the bowling alley, device, or structure after 11 p.m. and before sunrise in the morning, unless in the custody of a parent, guardian, or adult.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this Part 3, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Amusement device" means any electronic or mechanical device that is designed to provide amusement or entertainment and for which a fee is charged to operate or use.

para.heading: Illustrations.
para.text: "Amusement device" includes any of the following for which a fee is charged to operate or use:
video or electronic game;
computer console or Internet connection;
pinball or console machine;
bowling or shuffleboard machine;
pool table or poolette;
target machine;
baseball machine;
riding device;
claw machine, digger, or rotary merchandiser;
jukebox or other music player;
player piano;
peep show device; or
similar device.

para.heading: Exclusion.
para.text: "Amusement device" does not include:
a bona fide vending machine that does not incorporate an amusement or entertainment feature; or
a video lottery terminal licensed by the State under State Government Article, Title 9, Subtitle 1A.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of Finance of his or her designee.

para.heading: Simulated slot machine.
para.text: "Simulated slot machine" means any amusement device equipped with a knock-off device that enables an owner or custodian of the device to remove free plays or other game credits accumulated by a winning player.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide standard definition of “person”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-107.
For the Code-wide standard definition of “includes” and “including”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-105.

para.text: No person may permit any amusement device on his, her, or its premises to be used by the public unless the person first obtains from the Director a license for that device.
For a simulated slot machine, if the device has been registered by the owner under § 2-13 of this subtitle, the device is exempt from the license fee provided for in § 2-15(a) of this subtitle.

para.heading: Master's license.
para.text: No person may own, control, or possess more than 5 simulated slot machines unless that person first obtains from the Director a master's license.
The application for a license must be in the form that the Director requires.
In addition to any other information that the Director requires, the application must include:
the name, address, and telephone number of the applicant;
a description of the device or devices;
the location of the device or devices; and
the name, address, and telephone number of the owner of the device or devices.

para.heading: Transfers.
para.text: A device may be transferred to another licensee or to another location on:
approval from the Director; and
payment of the required transfer fee.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The owner of any amusement device that is located in the City must register that device with the Director.
The registration must be made in the form that the Director requires.
In addition to any other information that the Director requires, the registration must include:
the name, address, and telephone number of the owner;
the name, address, and telephone number of any lessee or other person who possesses the device; and
a description of the device.

para.heading: Supplemental information.
para.text: The owner must report to the Director, within 30 days of the event:
any newly acquired amusement devices;
the transfer of ownership or location of any registered amusement device; and
any other change in the registration information provided.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Each license issued and each registration filed under this Part 3 expires annually on December 31, unless renewed.

para.heading: Renewal.
para.text: The application for renewal of a license or registration must be made in the form that the Director requires.
The annual license fee for an amusement device is $180 per device.
The annual fee for a simulated slot machine master's license is $5,000.
The fee for a transfer of a licensed device is $10.
For simulated slot machines, the annual registration tax is as follows:
for each of the first 5 devices – $2,250 per device;
for each additional device up to the 20th – $1,750 per device; and
for each device in addition to 20 – $1,250 per device.
For all other types of amusement devices, the annual registration tax is as follows:
$200; plus
$50 per device.

para.heading: For less than full year..
para.text: The annual fee or tax for less than a full initial year is prorated quarterly.

para.heading: Payments not refundable.
para.text: No refunds, in whole or in part, may be made of any of the fees or taxes paid under this Part 3.

para.heading: Quarterly payments for simulated slot machines.

para.text: Fees and taxes required to be paid under this Part 3 for simulated slot machines may be made in equal quarterly installments if:
an additional service charge is paid with each quarterly payment;
all payments required by this Part for the previous year have been made; and
by January 1 of each year in which quarterly payments are to be made, the person responsible for the payments:
makes a written election, in the form required by the Director, to make quarterly payments; and
submits to the Director the full amount of that year's 1st quarterly installment plus the applicable service charge.
Quarterly installments of the license fee and registration tax for a simulated slot machine need not be paid for:

as to the license fee, any quarter that follows surrender to the Director of the device's license, together with evidence satisfactory to the Director that the device has been taken out of service for the rest of the license year; and

as to the registration tax, any quarter that follows surrender to the Director of the device's registration, together with evidence satisfactory to the Director that the device has been removed from the City for the rest of the license year.

If a master licensee surrenders the license and registration for 1 or more devices under this paragraph, together with evidence satisfactory to the Director that the devices have been taken out of service or removed from the City, as the case may be, for the rest of the license year, and is left with 5 or fewer devises being owned, controlled, or possessed by the licensee, the licensee may surrender the master license to the Director and need not pay any quarterly installment for any quarter that follows the surrender.
The rules and regulations adopted under § 2-17 of this subtitle must establish:
the amount of the service charge to be paid with each quarterly installment; and
a schedule indicating when quarterly payments are due each year.

section.heading: License to be posted.
section.text: The license for each amusement device must be:

para.text: securely affixed to the device; or
prominently displayed on the premises.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director shall adopt and enforce rules and regulations to carry out this Part 3.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The rules and regulations adopted under § 2-17 of this subtitle shall establish, subject to the appropriation of funds as approved by the Board of Estimates, a bounty program to reward persons who report devices being operated without the license or registration required by this Part.

para.heading: Source of reward.
para.text: The reward for a report shall be a set percentage, as specified in the rules and regulations but not to exceed 50%, of all fines and penalties that the City collects as a result of the report.

para.heading: Order.
para.text: If an amusement device is operated without a license or registration required by this subtitle, the Director shall issue a written order to the proprietor or other person in charge of the premises to:
immediately render the device inoperable; and
within 5 working days of the order:
obtain the required license or registration; or
remove the device from the premises.

para.heading: Confiscation or disablement.
para.text: The Director may confiscate the amusement device or render it inoperable if:
the device is not immediately rendered inoperable, as ordered under subsection (a)(1) of this section;
after having been rendered inoperable, the device is placed back in operation without the required license or registration; or
the required license or registration is not obtained within the period specified in subsection (a)(2) of this section and the device has not been removed from the premises.
If an amusement device is confiscated by the Director under this section, the owner may redeem the device on payment of:
a recovery charge, as established by the Board of Estimates from time to time; and
all outstanding registration and licensing taxes, fees, interest, and penalties.
The recovery charge will be set to cover the costs of transportation, storage, and other related expenses.
If a device is not redeemed within 180 days after its confiscation, the device is considered abandoned.
If an amusement device is rendered inoperable by the Director under this section, the owner may have the device reinstated on payment of:
a reinstatement charge, as established by the Board of Estimates from time to time; and
all outstanding registration and licensing taxes, fees, interest, and penalties.
The reinstatement charge will be set to cover all costs associated with rendering the device inoperable and operable.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this Part 3 or of a rule or regulation adopted under this Part 3 is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

section.heading: Minors under 16.
section.text: It is unlawful for the proprietor or person in charge of any premises on which there is a pinball machine (as that term is described and characterized in this article), which is or should be licensed under this article, to permit any person under 16 years of age to operate that device at any time.

section.heading: Minors 16 or older.
section.text: It also is unlawful for the proprietor or person in charge of the premises to permit any minor 16 years old or older to operate the device between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on any day between September 1 of any year and June 15 of the following year, except on Sundays and public school holidays if otherwise permitted by law.

section.heading: Identification required.
section.text: Any proprietor or person in charge who is asked to permit the playing of the device by any person whom he has reason to believe may be a minor within the terms of this subtitle, shall require identification and proof of age from the applicant.

section.heading: License required.
section.text: It shall be the duty of the owner of a for profit theater, motion picture theater, hall used for entertainment, sports center, or museum, before permitting any person to use such facility for gain, to obtain a license from the Director of Finance for an annual fee of $165.

para.heading: Presence on premises.
para.text: It is unlawful for any owner, operator, servant, agent, or employee of any theater, concert hall, dance hall, club, or other place of public amusement knowingly to permit on the premises of that place of public amusement, between the hours of 9 a.m. and 3 p.m., any child under the age of 16, unless:
the child is accompanied by his or her parent or guardian;
the child has a permit issued by the Board of Education or the principal of the parochial or private school having jurisdiction, authorizing his or her absence from school; or
the school at which the child is enrolled is not in session.

para.heading: Operating certain devices.
para.text: It also is unlawful for any owner, operator, servant, agent, or employee of any theater, concert hall, dance hall, club, or other place where public amusement is provided, including those places where coin-operated amusement devices, including electronic games, are provided for the public use, to knowingly permit the operation of these coin-operated amusement devices, including electronic games, between the hours of 9 a.m. and 3 p.m. by any child under the age of 16, unless the school at which the child is enrolled is not in session.

section.heading: Minors at burlesque shows.
section.text: It is unlawful for any owner, operator, servant, agent, or employee of any burlesque show, whether it be held in a permanent theater, side show, carnival, or by a private organization, to allow on the premises any child, male or female, under the age of 16.

para.heading: License required.
para.text: A license is required for regular dancing academies or places used for instruction in the art of dancing.

para.heading: Fee.
para.text: [The licensee] shall pay an annual license fee of $50 for such privilege.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The tax or license for musical parties shall be:
$5 per night, when the admission fee does not exceed 25¢;
$8 per night, when it exceeds 25¢ but not over 50¢; and
$10 per night, when it exceeds 50¢.

para.heading: Charitable exceptions.
para.text: But the Mayor is authorized to grant, free of expense, all applications for license for concerts or performances of any kind, where the proceeds are intended for charitable purposes.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this Part 7, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Amusement device.
para.text: "Amusement device" has the meaning stated in § 2-11 of this article.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Animated riding device" means an amusement device that provides a moving ride or activated operation.

para.heading: Illustrations.
para.text: "Animated riding device" includes any rocking horse, airplane, boat, spaceship, or similar device.

para.heading: License required.
para.text: No person, firm, corporation, or other entity may operate any animated riding device unless the device is licensed under Part 3 of this subtitle.

para.heading: Fee.
para.text: Notwithstanding the fees set in Part 3 of this subtitle, the annual fee for an animated riding device license is $25 per device.

para.heading: On application.
para.text: Before issuing any such license, the Director of Finance shall have such animated riding device inspected by the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development and shall obtain from him a certificate to the effect that the animated riding device has been inspected and is mechanically safe for operation.

para.heading: Semi-annually.
para.text: As a condition for retaining any such license, the applicant shall present to the Director of Finance at intervals of not more than 6 months thereafter, a similar certificate of inspection and safe condition.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Director of Finance shall require each applicant for a license herein provided for to furnish proof of financial responsibility in the form of a written certificate from an insurance carrier authorized to transact business in the State of Maryland.

para.heading: Scope; amount.
para.text: Said certificate shall state that the applicant is insured against liability for damage including death or injury to persons and damage to property due to faulty equipment or negligence, and indemnifying the City against any suit or suits, losses, claims, damages, or expense to which the City may be subjected by reason of any damage to property or person, including death, or injury to the public highways and other public property done in or in connection with the transportation, erection, operation, maintenance, and supervision of such animated riding devices and said certificate shall be provided in an amount which in the discretion of the Director of Finance will adequately protect the public.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Where the applicant is a nonresident, said applicant and said insurance carrier shall execute a power of attorney authorizing the Director of Finance to accept on their behalf service of notices, processes, and any action arising out of the ownership, operation, maintenance, or in any wise connected with said animated riding devices, while they are within the confines of the limits of the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Corporations.
para.text: In the event that a nonresident corporation applies for a license, the Director of Finance shall issue said license provided:
the nonresident corporation complies with all conditions herein contained; and

in addition thereto, submits with its application for said license a certificate from the State Department of Assessments and Taxation certifying that the nonresident corporation is a duly constituted corporation authorized to do business in the State of Maryland.

section.heading: Building Code.
section.text: The provisions of § 432.9 of the Baltimore City Building Code, which relate to the electrical and mechanical requirements for certain circuses and carnivals, apply in all respects to the animated riding devices provided for in this Part 7. However, no other provisions of § 432 of the Building Code apply to animated riding devices.

section.heading: License required.
section.text: No person, firm, corporation, or other entity may operate any type of ride or riding device mounted on mobile equipment unless the device is licensed under Part 3 of this subtitle.

para.heading: On application.
para.text: Before issuing any such license, the Director of Finance shall have such ride or riding device mounted on mobile equipment inspected by the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development and shall obtain from him a certificate to the effect that such ride or riding device mounted on mobile equipment has been inspected and is mechanically safe for operation.

para.heading: Semi-annually.
para.text: The applicant shall as a condition of retaining any such license present to the Director of Finance a similar certificate of inspection and safe condition at intervals of not more than 6 months thereafter.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Director of Finance shall require each applicant for a license herein provided for to furnish proof of financial responsibility in the form of a written certificate from an insurance carrier authorized to transact business in the State of Maryland.

para.heading: Scope; amount.
para.text: Said certificate shall state that the applicant is insured against liability for damage including death or injury to persons and damage to property due to faulty equipment or negligence, and indemnifying the City against any suit or suits, losses, claims, damages, or expense to which the City may be subjected by reason of any damage to property or person, including death, or injury to the public highways and other public property done in or in connection with the transportation, erection, operation, maintenance, and supervision of such ride or riding device mounted on mobile equipment, and said certificate shall be provided in an amount which in the discretion of the Director of Finance will adequately protect the public.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Where the applicant is a nonresident, said applicant and said insurance carrier shall execute a power of attorney authorizing the Director of Finance to accept service on their behalf of notices, processes, and any action arising out of the ownership, operation, maintenance, or in any wise connected with said ride or riding device mounted on mobile equipment while it is within the confines of the limits of the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Corporations.
para.text: In the event that a nonresident corporation applies for a license, the Director of Finance shall issue said license provided:
the said nonresident corporation complies with all conditions herein contained; and

in addition thereto, submits with its application for said license a certificate from the State Department of Assessments and Taxation certifying that the nonresident corporation is a duly constituted corporation authorized to do business in the State of Maryland.

section.heading: Building Code; time limit on operation.

para.heading: Building Code.
para.text: Subject to a licencee's compliance with subsection (b) of this section, the provisions of § 432 {"Circuses and Carnivals"} of the Baltimore City Building Code, which regulates circuses and carnivals, do apply to applications and licenses to operate any type of ride or riding device mounted on mobile equipment.

para.heading: Time limit on operation.
para.text: No licensee may operate a ride or riding device mounted on mobile equipment in any 1 block for longer than 1 hour.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Amusement device.
para.text: "Amusement device" has the meaning stated in § 2-11 of this article.

para.heading: Commissioner.
para.text: "Commissioner" means the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development or the Commissioner's designee.

para.heading: Zoning Board.
para.text: "Zoning Board" means the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals of Baltimore City.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide standard definition of “person”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-107.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as specified in subsection (b) of this section, any person who proposes to locate 1 or more amusement devices in an establishment for the use of the general public must first obtain an amusement device location permit from the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: A location permit is not required under this subtitle for any amusement arcade or recreation center that is operated by the City.

section.heading: Applications.
section.text: The application must be in the form and contain the information that the Commissioner requires.

para.heading: Posting required.
para.text: Before a location permit (other than a renewal permit) may be issued, the applicant must post the proposed location for 15 days.

para.heading: 9 or fewer objections.
para.text: If, within the 15-day posting period, the Commissioner receives no more than 9 written objections from persons within the same election precinct as the proposed location, the permit may be issued.

para.heading: 10 or more objections.
para.text: If, within the 15-day posting period, the Commissioner receives 10 or more written objections from persons within the same election precinct as the proposed location, the Commissioner must refer the matter to the Zoning Board for a hearing.
On referral by the Commissioner, the Zoning Board must hold a public hearing on the proposed location permit.
Parties in interest and citizens must be given an opportunity to be heard at the hearing.

para.heading: Denial to be in writing.
para.text: Any denial of a permit must be in writing, with specific reasons given for the denial.

para.heading: Reapplication waiting period.
para.text: If the Zoning Board denies a permit, then the applicant may not reapply for a permit for at least 12 months.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Each permit expires annually on June 30 and is renewable as provided in this section.
To renew a permit, the permit holder must apply no less than 30 days nor more than 60 days before the permit expires.
The renewal application must be in the form and contain the information that the Commissioner requires.

On filing the renewal application and payment of the renewal fee, the Commissioner must approve the application unless 10 or more written objections from persons within the same election precinct as the location in question are filed with the Commissioner no later than 30 days before the permit expires.

If the Commissioner receives 10 or more timely objections from persons within the same election precinct as the location in question, the Commissioner must refer the matter to the Zoning Board for a hearing.

para.heading: Annual fee.
para.text: The annual fee for the permit is $15, payable on or before July 1 of each year.

para.heading: Fee not refundable.
para.text: No refunds may be made of this fee, in whole or in part.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: On a finding that an applicant or permit holder has committed one of the offenses specified in subsection (b) of this section, the Zoning Board may:
deny the permit or permit renewal; or
suspend the permit for not less than 30 days nor more than 90 days.

para.heading: Grounds.
para.text: The Zoning Board may take action under subsection (a) of this section for any of the following causes:
failing or refusing to comply with any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle;
making any material false statement in any application for an initial or renewal permit;
violating any provision of the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article, Health Code Article, or Zoning Code Article, or of any other ordinance, rule, or regulation of the City;
conviction of an owner, operator, or employee of the establishment of any violation of City Code Article 19, § 34-6 {"Daytime and Nighttime Curfews: Prohibited conduct of establishments"};
conviction of an owner, operator, or employee of the establishment of any violation of City Code Article 19, Subtitle 25 {"Loitering — General"};

permitting the installation, maintenance, or operation of amusement devices in any way that impairs the safety, health, or general welfare of patrons or of the public in the immediate vicinity of the premises;
lack of accessibility for fire and police protection; or
lack of accessibility of light and air.

para.heading: Written decision and order.
para.text: The Zoning Board must issue a written decision and order on any application for a permit or renewal application within 5 days of the hearing on the matter.

Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Zoning Board may adopt rules and regulations for procedural purposes to carry out this subtitle.
These rules and regulations become effective 7 days after they are filed with the Department of Legislative Reference.

Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Commissioner may adopt rules and regulations to carry out the administrative provisions of this subtitle.
These rules and regulations become effective 7 days after they are filed with the Department of Legislative Reference.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person required to obtain a location permit who fails to do so is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $15 for each day of the violation.

annotation.text: In the 1950 City Code, the then-provisions of this subtitle were codified as Article 38, §§47 through 58 {“Licenses and Numbers”}. In the 1966 Code (legalized by Ord. 66-774, effective April 18, 1966), those provisions, as amended in the intervening years, were recodified as Article 31, §§60 through 73 {“Licenses and Numbers”}. In the same year, however, Ord. 66-887 was enacted, effective October 29, 1966, to repeal all of Article 38, §§47 through 58 of the 1950 Code and to ordain a new §49 under the new subtitle “Licenses for Vehicles and Vessels”. Neither of the 1966 enactments gave effect to the other.

Whether Ord. 66-887 was ever given effect is uncertain. That it was soon forgotten, though, is quite evident: In 1975, the Mayor and City Council enacted Ord. 75-881, which amended Article 31, §§ 60 through 73 of the 1966 Code (the same provisions as those that had been repealed by Ord. 66-887) and recodified them as Article 15, §§92 through 105 under the current subtitle designation “Carriages, Wagons, Boats and Scows”.
This recodification conforms to the later enactment, Ord. 75-881 (and subsequent amendments), and does not purport to give effect to the long-lost Ord. 66-887.

section.heading: Issuance of license.
section.text: The Director of Finance shall issue all licenses for and numbers of carriages, wagons, and other vehicles, boats, and scows as enumerated in § 6-2.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-009

para.heading: Registration number to be displayed.
para.text: All hackney coaches, buggies, cabs, and gigs, kept for hire, and all wagons, furniture carriages, carts, drays, package carts, boats (other than open rowboats of every description), and scows, owned or commonly used or employed in the City, shall be numbered with plain conspicuous figures, on plates of tin, to be provided as hereinafter directed, to begin with number 1 and so on progressively.

para.heading: Owners to register annually.
para.text: The owner or owners of such carriages, boats, or scows, shall:
appear annually at the office of the Director of Finance;
have entered in a book kept for that purpose:
his or her name and place of abode;
the description of every carriage, boat, or scow by him or her owned; and
the number thereon to be affixed; and
take out a license containing his or her number, and signed by the Director of Finance, with the City Seal affixed to it.

para.heading: Compliance required.
para.text: No owner is permitted to use or employ, or let for hire on any street, lane, or alley, nor in any water within the City, any hackney coach, buggy, cab, or gig, kept for hire, wagon, furniture carriage, cart, dray, package cart, boat (other than an open rowboat), or scow, until he or she first complies with the regulations contained in this subtitle.

section.heading: "Commonly used or employed" defined.
section.text: Any vehicle mentioned in § 6-2 which is used upon the streets of Baltimore City upon more than 1 day per week, on an average, for a period of more than 3 months in any 1 year, shall be considered as "commonly used or employed", in the City, within the meaning of said § 6-2.

section.heading: Term of licenses.
section.text: All licenses shall terminate on January 1 annually, but the holder of a license can at any time between that time and the January 30 take out a new license without being subject to penalty.

para.heading: Annual fee.
para.text: The owner of any carriage, boat, or scow shall pay the following annual license fee:
Hackney coaches, cabs, or other pleasure carriages kept for hire, and wagons, carts, or other carriages of burden drawn by 1 or more horses — $20
Boats (other than open rowboats), water taxis, and scows — $80
Package carts — $10

para.heading: Payment.
para.text: The owners shall pay the fees to the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Transfer of license.
para.text: Transfer of any of these licenses must be made at the Office of the City Collector, and no charge will be made therefor.

para.heading: Proof of identity, etc.
para.text: No owner licensed as provided in § 6-2 of this subtitle shall rent a vehicle to any person without first requiring proof of the identity (which shall include a clear photograph and a record of fingerprints) and address of the person proposing to rent the vehicle.

para.heading: Records to be kept.
para.text: Said owner shall keep a permanent record on his premises of the names and addresses of all persons renting a vehicle or vehicles from him and the date of each rental.

It is the duty of the Director of Finance, annually, on or before January 1 in each year, to purchase a sufficient number of tin plates, numbered with plain conspicuous figures, beginning with number 1, and so on progressively, 2 of each to correspond with the number of the carriage, boat, or scow, and also to purchase suitable dies for the arithmetical numbers.
The figures standing for the year in which those numbers were issued shall be stamped on the top of each numbered plate.
The plate shall be of suitable size and description in the discretion of the Director of Finance, and paid for out of the appropriation for general licenses.

It is the duty of the Director of Finance to furnish for each licensed carriage, boat, or scow, 2 of these tin plates, with number corresponding with the number of the license, and the record of that carriage, boat, or scow.
These numbered plates shall be fastened on each side of and the most conspicuous part of the carriage, boat, or scow, so that the numbers may be plainly seen.

para.heading: Private carriage license.
para.text: The Director of Finance shall furnish to those who take out private carriage licenses, a single number, painted upon a tin plate that shall not measure more than 2¾ x 2 inches, which number shall be placed upon the hindermost part of the hind axle of the carriage by the owner or owners.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-032

para.heading: Right to display own numbers.
para.text: All persons who take out licenses under this subtitle are hereby authorized to provide numbers for their carriages, wagons, and other vehicles, of such design as to them may seem proper, such numbers to conform with their license, the same to be in a conspicuous place; provided, that the number furnished by the Director of Finance be nevertheless attached to such carriage or wagon in such place inside the carriage or wagon as he may direct.

para.heading: Notice.
para.text: All persons availing themselves of the privilege of this section can retain the same number from year to year by annual notice of the Director of Finance previous to December 20 and those desiring to retain their old numbers may do so by similar notice.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-032

section.heading: False entries.
section.text: No person may:

para.text: cause or procure a false entry to be made of any such carriage, boat, or scow;
after a true entry, alter the number of his carriage, boat, or scow, being registered; or
not having a license, permit a number to be fixed to or remain on his or her carriage, boat, or scow.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-032

para.heading: License required.
para.text: No owner of any carriage shall use the same in carrying or transporting any person or persons within the said City for hire or pay, unless such owner shall:
appear at the office of the Director of Finance and make entry and take out license as aforesaid;
number such carriage on the middle panel or other conspicuous place, of each side, with plain and conspicuous figures; and
the same renew annually.

para.heading: Applicability of other regulations.
para.text: Such owner shall be subject to all the other rules and regulations herein contained, respecting wagoners, carters, and draymen, and shall be liable to the same forfeitures and penalties upon the noncompliance with or violation of any such rule or regulation.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-032

section.heading: Numbers and licenses.
section.text: It is unlawful for the owner or owners of any carriage, wagon, cart, dray, package cart, furniture wagon, boat, or scow to retain or suffer to be placed on that vehicle any other number than one corresponding with the license for the vehicle.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-032

section.heading: Withdrawal of license.
section.text: It shall be the duty of the Mayor to withdraw the license from any vehicle licensed by the City, the driver of which shall violate a 2nd time any of the provisions of this Code regulating the speed of horses and vehicles.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Rev. Ords. 1858-032

section.heading: Subtitle to be advertised.
section.text: It shall be the duty of the Director of Finance to notify all persons annually of the necessity of attending to the provisions of this subtitle, by advertising the same at least 10 days previous to January 1 in a daily paper of general circulation in Baltimore City, and of the privilege accorded by § 6-9 by advertising the same at least 5 days previous to December 20 in a daily paper of the City.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The following terms have the meanings indicated unless their context clearly indicates otherwise.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Employment agency" means any sole proprietorship, partnership, association, corporation, contractor, or subcontractor who, for a fee, paid by either the prospective employer, employee, or both:
procures or offers or attempts to procure employees for persons seeking the service of employees;
procures or offers or attempts to procure employment for persons, seeking employment; or
engages in the business of furnishing information to persons seeking employment for the purpose of enabling the persons to secure employment.

para.heading: Inclusions.
para.text: "Employment agency" includes:
any person conducting a business which consists of employing individuals directly for the purpose of furnishing part-time or temporary help to others; and
any person, partnership, or corporation:
whose fee is paid 100% by the employer, and
that does not collect any money from an applicant.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Employment agency" does not include:

bona fide educational, religious, charitable, fraternal, or benevolent organizations in which no fee, commission, or other charge is made for services rendered other than the ordinary membership dues;
bona fide labor organizations undertaking to secure or securing work for their own members;
bona fide employers' organizations undertaking to secure or securing help for their own members; or
any person who merely conducts a business that:
receives a fee that is paid wholly by an employer;
does not collect money from an individual seeking employment; and
does not require an individual seeking employment to make a contract.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide standard definition of “person”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-107.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: No person shall carry on the business of an employment agency without first obtaining a license to conduct an employment agency.

para.heading: Issuance, fees, records.
para.text: It shall be the duty of the Director of Finance:
to issue licenses for employment agencies annually;
to charge for each and every such license the sum of $250; and
to keep a record of the name and place of business of each and every person, firm, or corporation, who may take out such license, which record shall be kept on file in his office.

section.heading: Exhibition of license.
section.text: Every person, firm, or corporation, who shall take out a license under § 7-2, and who shall conduct an employment agency under such license:

para.text: shall register his, her, or its full name and address with the Director of Finance during the 1st week of January in each year; and
shall exhibit on the front of the building in which such business shall be conducted, a sign containing:
the words, "Licensed Employment Agency"; and
the name of the person, firm, or corporation so conducting such business.

section.heading: Scope of subtitle.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

para.text: judicial sales;
sales made by a licensed auctioneer; or
sales made by a duly licensed business, such as a grocery store.

section.heading: Limit on frequency and duration of sales.

para.heading: 1 sale per 6-month period.
para.text: It is unlawful to conduct more than 1 public sale of tangible personal property commonly known as garage sales or lawn sales on residential property within any 6-month period.

para.heading: 3 days per sale.
para.text: Any 1 sale shall not be conducted for more than 3 consecutive days.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person violating any provision of this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, is subject to a fine not exceeding $100 for each and every violation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Business.
para.text: "Business" means any place of business or commercial activity conducted by a person, whether sales, service, rental, professional, or otherwise.

para.heading: Finance Department; Department.
para.text: "Finance Department" or "Department" means the Baltimore City Department of Finance.

para.heading: Finance Director; Director.
para.text: "Finance Director" or "Director" means the Director of the Finance Department or the Director's designee.

para.heading: Impact area.
para.text: "Impact area" means the area:
within the same election precinct as that in which a business is located; and
if a different precinct, within the election precinct of the block face opposing the block face in which a business is located.

para.heading: Late-night operations license; license.
para.text: "Late-night operations license" or "license" means a license issued under this subtitle.

For the Code-wide standard definition of “includes” and “including”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-105.
