section.heading: Rules, regulations, and forms.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Finance Department must adopt rules, regulations, and forms to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as specified in subsection (b) of this section, this subtitle applies to all businesses that are located in any Residential Zoning District, Office-Residential Zoning District, or C-1, C-1-E, C-1-VC, C-2, or C-3 Commercial Zoning District.

para.heading: Exceptions.
para.text: This subtitle does not apply to:
a hotel or motel;
a restaurant or tavern operating during hours authorized by its alcoholic beverage license;
the sale of motor vehicle fuels;
the provision of emergency medical or veterinary care;
a video lottery facility operating during hours authorized by its State Video Lottery Operating license; or
drive-through food-service windows, if:
all indoor sales and dining areas are closed to the public during late-night hours; and
no pedestrians are served at these windows during late-night hours.

section.heading: License required.
section.text: No business in a Residential Zoning District, Office-Residential Zoning District, or C-1, C-1-E, C-1-VC, C-2, or C-3 Commercial Zoning District may be open to the public at any time between the hours of midnight and 5 a.m. without having first obtained a late-night operations license under this subtitle.

section.heading: Conditional license for late-night delivery services.
section.text: The Finance Department may issue a late-night operations license for a business to operate a late-night delivery-only service, conditioned upon all indoor sales and dining areas being closed to the public during late-night hours.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Every application for an initial or renewal license must be in the form and contain the information that the Finance Department requires.

para.heading: Multiple businesses owned or franchised by same person.
para.text: Any person that owns or is the franchisor of 2 or more businesses subject to this subtitle may:
submit a joint application for an initial or renewal license for each of those businesses; and
remit in one lump-sum payment the aggregate fees owed for those businesses.

para.heading: Posting and notice required.
para.text: On filing an application for an initial license, the applicant must, in accordance with the Finance Department's rules and regulations:
post the premises for 15 days; and

within 5 days of the filing, send notice of the application by email or by certified or registered mail to the City Councilmember who represents the Councilmanic District in which the business is located.

If, within the 15-day posting period, the Department receives no more than 9 written objections from real property owners, commercial tenants that are not themselves holders of or applicants for a late-night operations license, or residents within the impact area of the business, the Department must grant or deny the license within 15 days after the last day of the 15-day posting period.
A denial must be based solely on one or more of the following factors:
any cause for denial that is specified in § 9-16 {"Denial, suspension, or revocation"} of this subtitle;
the specific days and hours proposed for late-night operations;
the lack or inadequacy of an indoor and outdoor security plan; and
the inability or unwillingness of the applicant to accept reasonable conditions on the license to protect the public health, safety, and welfare
The notice of a denial must:
state the reasons for the denial; and
notify the applicant of the applicant's right to appeal to the Finance Director.
Within 30 days of receiving the notice of denial, the applicant may appeal to the Finance Director for an administrative review of the application.

If, within the 15-day posting period, the Department receives 10 or more written objections from real property owners, commercial tenants that are not themselves holders of or applicants for a late-night operations license, or residents within the impact area of the business, the Department must:
deny the application; and
within 7 days after the last day of the 15-day posting period, notify the applicant of the denial and of the applicant's right to appeal to the Finance Director.
Within 30 days of receiving the notice of denial, the applicant may appeal to the Finance Director for an administrative review of the application.

para.heading: Finance Director to decide.
para.text: Within 30 days after the timely filing of an appeal, the Finance Director must notify the applicant in writing of his or her decision:
to affirm the denial of the license; or
to direct the Department to grant the license.

para.heading: Considerations.
para.text: In reviewing an application, the Finance Director must consider:
all letters submitted in opposition to or support of the application;
any cause for denial that is specified in § 9-16 {"Denial, suspension, or revocation"} of this subtitle;
the specific days and hours proposed for late-night operations;
the adequacy of an indoor and outdoor security plan, including any evaluation made by the Police Commissioner or his or her designee; and
the ability and willingness of the applicant to accept reasonable conditions on the license to protect the public health, safety, and welfare.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Each late-night operations license expires annually on the anniversary of its issuance and is renewable as provided in this section.

para.heading: Application for renewal.
para.text: To renew a license, the licensee must:
apply no less than 60 days nor more than 90 days before the license expires; and
in accordance with the Finance Department's rules and regulations, post the premises for 15 days.

para.heading: Approval.
para.text: On filing the renewal application and payment of the renewal fee, the Finance Department may approve the application, except as provided in subsection (d) of this section.

If, within the 15-day posting period, 10 or more written objections from real property owners, commercial tenants that are not themselves holders of or applicants for a late-night operations license, or residents within the impact area of the business, the Department must:
deny the application; and
within 7 days after the last day of the 15-day posting period, notify the applicant of the denial and of the applicant's right to appeal to the Finance Director.
Within 30 days of receiving the notice of denial, the applicant may appeal to the Finance Director for an administrative review of the application.
The filing of an appeal to the Finance Director does not stay the decision of the Department pending the Director's decision.
The considerations and decision of the Finance Director shall be as provided in § 9-9 of this subtitle.

section.heading: Fee for license.
section.text: The annual license fee is $460 per business, subject to adjustment in accordance with the City Fee Policy.

section.heading: Waiting period after denial.
section.text: If a license or renewal license is denied under this subtitle, the applicant may not reapply for at least 12 months from the date of the final decision of the Department or, if judicial review of that decision was obtained, from the date of the final court decision.

section.heading: Denial, suspension, or revocation.
section.text: The Finance Department or, on appeal, the Finance Director may deny, suspend, or revoke a late-night operations license or renewal license for any of the following causes:

para.text: failing to pay the applicable license fee on or before the due date;
making any material false statement in any application for an initial or renewal license;
failing to abate within 30 days of receipt any notice or citation for violating any provision of the City Building, Fire, and Related Codes Article, Health Code Article, or Zoning Code Article; or
failing to comply with any provision of:
this subtitle;
a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle; or
a condition imposed under this subtitle on the license.

section.heading: Fines.
section.text: For any violation that is cause for suspending or revoking a license, the Finance Department or, on appeal, the Finance Director may, instead of or in addition to suspending or revoking the license, impose a civil fine of:

para.text: for a 1st offense, not more than $500; and
for any subsequent offense, not more than $1,000.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section does not apply to the denial of a license or a renewal license under § 9-8 or § 9-10(d).

Within 30 days of receiving the Department's decision to deny, suspend, or revoke a license or to impose a civil fine, an aggrieved applicant or licensee may appeal the sanction imposed to the Finance Director for an administrative review.
The filing of an appeal to the Finance Director stays the decision of the Department pending the Director's decision.
Within 30 days after the timely filing of an appeal, the Finance Director must notify the applicant or licensee in writing of his or her decision.
The Finance Director may affirm, reject, increase, or otherwise modify any or all of the sanctions from which the appeal was taken.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: A person aggrieved by a decision of the Finance Director under this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.
The filing of a petition for judicial review does not stay the decision of the Finance Director.
However, on motion and after hearing, the Court may grant a stay as provided in the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates or who neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 or imprisonment for not more than 6 months or both fine and imprisonment.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues after notification constitutes a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Hotel.
para.text: "Hotel" means any building, including any motel, that:
contains sleeping accommodations for more than 5 persons; and
is open to the transient public.

para.heading: Housing Department; Department.
para.text: "Housing Department" or "Department" means the City Department of Housing and Community Development.

para.heading: Human trafficking.
para.text: "Human trafficking" means:
sex trafficking in which a commercial sex act is induced by force, fraud, or coercion, or in which the person induced to perform a commercial sex act has not attained 18 years of age; or

the recruitment, harboring, transportation, provision, or obtaining of a person for labor or services, through the use of force, fraud, or coercion for the purpose of subjection to involuntary servitude, peonage, debt bondage, or slavery.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide standard definition of “person”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-107.

section.heading: Registration required.
section.text: No person may operate a hotel in Baltimore City without first registering the hotel with the Housing Department on the form required by that Department.

section.heading: Rules, regulations, and forms.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Housing Department must adopt rules, regulations, and forms to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Hotel employees to be trained.
para.text: Any person who owns or operates a hotel within the City must provide training on how to identify human trafficking activities and human trafficking victims:
to all new hotel employees, within 90 days of hire; and
to all hotel employees, at least once every two years.

para.heading: Training to be approved by Health Commissioner.
para.text: The anti-trafficking training program required by this section must be approved by the Health Commissioner as appropriate for training employees on how to identify human trafficking activities and human trafficking victims.

para.heading: Certification required.
para.text: Beginning in calendar year 2020, any person who owns or operates a hotel within the City must annually certify to the Housing Commissioner, no later than December 31 of each year, that all hotel employees have completed the training required by this section.

annotations.annotation: This section were amended by Ordinance 19-241, effective October 19, 2019, to, among other things, require biennial training for all employees and to modify the filing deadline for annual certifications of compliance.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: After the issuance to a hotel of a multiple-family dwelling license required by City Code Article 13 {"Housing and Urban Renewal"}, § 5-4 {"License required"}, the hotel must prominently display a sign stating that the facility has provided training to all employees on how to identify human trafficking activities and human trafficking victims.

para.heading: Manner of display.
para.text: The sign required by subsection (a) of this section must be prominently displayed in the lobby of the hotel in the form and manner required by the Department.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates or who neglects or refuses to comply with any provision of this subtitle or of any rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 12 months or both fine and imprisonment.

para.heading: Each day after notice a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues after notification constitutes a separate offense.

para.heading: Board.
para.text: Board means the Board of Licenses for Massage Establishments.

para.heading: Massage.
para.text: "Massage" means the administration by any person of any method of exerting or applying pressure, friction, moisture, heat, or cold to the human body, or the rubbing, stroking, kneading, pounding, or tapping of the human body by any physical or mechanical means for any form of consideration.

para.heading: Massage establishment.
para.text: "Massage establishment" means any building, place, or operation wherein a massage is administered or permitted to be administered for any form of consideration.

para.heading: Massage therapist.
para.text: "Massage therapist" means an individual who has completed at least 500 hours of training at, and has received certification from, a school which has a massage training program approved by the Commissioner of Health and by a professional organization having the authority to approve massage training programs.

para.heading: Massagist.
para.text: "Massagist" means any person who administers a massage for any form of consideration.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide standard definition of “person”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-107.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In interpreting and applying this subtitle, the following rules of interpretation apply:
those contained in Subtitles 2 and 3 of the City Code's General Provisions Article; and
any additional rules contained in this section.

para.heading: Building.
para.text: The word "building" shall be deemed to apply to any part or portion of such building.

para.heading: Tense.
para.text: Words used in the present tense shall include the future.

section.heading: Purpose and intent.
section.text: It is the declared purpose and intent of the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore in ordaining this subtitle to protect and preserve the health, safety, and welfare of the inhabitants of this City by providing a program for regulating massage establishments in order to eliminate the social difficulties that now exist in many massage parlors and to promote higher standards of health, sanitation, and professional competence therein.

section.heading: Exemptions.
section.text: This subtitle shall not apply to:

para.text: physicians, surgeons, osteopaths, chiropractors, or therapists who are duly licensed to practice their respective professions in the State of Maryland or who are permitted to practice temporarily under the auspices of any associate or establishment duly licensed in the State of Maryland, while in the course of their licensed business or profession;
nurses and practical nurses, who are registered under the laws of this State and operating under a physician's direction;
any duly licensed hospital, medical clinic, or nursing home;
a trainer of any duly constituted athletic team while in the normal course of his duties;

any bona fide health spa or health club offering or providing massages solely incidental to the furnishing of facilities for and instruction in physical fitness and actually occupying premises of not less than 3,000 square feet, of which not more than 10% is used for massages;

any corporation or association which is organized and operated exclusively for social or athletic purposes and which offers or provides massages solely incidental to the furnishing of facilities for such purposes and which actually occupies premises of not less than 3,000 square feet, of which area not more than 10% is used for massages; or
massage therapists.

section.heading: License required for massage establishments.
section.text: No person shall maintain, operate, or conduct a massage establishment within the City of Baltimore without a license previously issued by the Director of Finance.

section.heading: Registration required for massagists.
section.text: No person maintaining, operating, or conducting a massage establishment shall employ, or otherwise allow, any individual to perform as a massagist, and no individual shall perform as a massagist, unless such individual shall have first been duly registered as a massagist for that particular massage establishment with the Board of Licenses for Massage Establishments.

section.heading: Board of Licenses for Massage Establishments.

para.heading: Board established.
para.text: There is hereby created and established a Board of Licenses for Massage Establishments, with the membership, powers, and duties as in this subtitle provided.
The Board shall be composed of:
the Commissioner of Health;
the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development; and
the Chief of the Fire Department.
A member of the Board may designate a duly authorized officer of his Department to serve in his capacity as may be necessary from time to time.

para.heading: Officers.
para.text: The members of the Board shall annually elect a chairman from among the members of the Board and may appoint a Secretary.

para.heading: Compensation; expenses.
para.text: The members of the Board shall receive no compensation for services rendered by them as members of the Board, but they shall be reimbursed for all necessary and proper expenses incurred in the discharge of their duties.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Board is authorized and empowered to promulgate and adopt rules and regulations to carry out the purpose and intent of this subtitle.

para.heading: Notice of applications.
para.text: The Board through its rules, shall provide for the notification of civic associations of applications received from massage establishments within the district served by the association.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed subsection (e) to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Required information.
para.text: Applicants for a license under § 11-5 shall file upon a form provided by the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development a signed application, subject to the law relating to perjury, setting forth the following information:
a definition of service to be provided;
the address where it is proposed to conduct the business for which application is made;
the name, local and permanent addresses, and local telephone number of each applicant;

if applicant is a corporation, the state of corporation, the names and residence addresses of each of the officers and directors of said corporation and of each stockholder owning more than 10% of the stock of the corporation, and the address of the corporation itself, if different from the address of the massage establishment;

if applicant is a partnership, the names and residence addresses of each of the partners including limited partners, and the address of the partnership itself, if different from the address of the massage establishment;
a photograph, at least 2 inches by 2 inches in size, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner;
description: height, weight, age, date of birth, color of hair and eyes, other distinguishing physical characteristics of the applicant;
a statement indicating whether the applicant has ever been licensed to practice or carry on the same business and, if so, when and where it was last practiced or carried on;

a statement that the applicant has never been convicted of any crime, motor vehicle laws excepted, or convicted of violation of any municipal code or ordinance or, if so convicted, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty imposed;

the number of rooms to be occupied by the business, together with a drawing of the interior arrangement and a list of the proposed equipment with a brief description of each piece of proposed equipment; and

the name and address of each massagist who is or will be employed in said establishment, together with a statement of his/her individual qualifications and the name and address of the last place of business where each individual worked.

para.heading: Application fee.
para.text: The sum of $25 shall accompany the application to reimburse the City for the cost of investigation, which sum shall be retained by the City whether the license is granted or denied.

para.heading: Successor license.
para.text: An application for a successor license shall be filed with the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development on or before April 1 of each year.

para.heading: Referral to Board.
para.text: The application shall be referred by the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development to the Board for investigation and recommendation.

para.heading: Police interview.
para.text: Before the recommendation is made, the applicant shall be personally interviewed by the Police Commissioner or by his duly authorized representative.

para.heading: Investigation of qualifications.
para.text: The Board, in addition to investigating the items set forth in the application, shall also investigate the qualifications of the applicant.

para.heading: Reasons for denial to be in writing.
para.text: If the recommendation of the Board, after investigation, is that the applicant not be licensed, the Board shall state the reasons therefore in writing.

para.heading: Judicial review.
para.text: An applicant aggrieved by a decision under this subtitle may seek judicial review of that decision by petition to the Circuit Court for Baltimore City in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: Appellate review.
para.text: A party to the judicial review may appeal the court's final judgment to the Court of Special Appeals in accordance with the Maryland Rules of Procedure.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: If the recommendation of the Board is favorable, the Director of Finance shall, upon payment of a license fee in the sum of $1,500 issue a license to the applicant.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Every license so granted shall terminate on July 1 annually, or until a successor license is issued or denied by the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Display.
para.text: The Director of Finance shall issue a certificate of license which shall at all times be prominently displayed inside the massage establishment.

section.heading: License not transferable.
section.text: No massage establishment license shall be transferable.

para.heading: General operations.
para.text: It is unlawful for any person maintaining, operating, or conducting a massage establishment to:
remain open or provide services any time between the hours of midnight and 8 a.m., Official City Time;
provide treatment at the same time to persons of the opposite sex in the same room or quarters; or
provide to any person at any time any service which the Health Commissioner may reasonably consider to be dangerous to health or safety.

para.heading: Violation of State law.
para.text: No person conducting a massage establishment shall tolerate on the premises any activity or behavior prohibited by the laws of the State, particularly, but not exclusively, those sections within Article 27 of the Annotated Code of Maryland proscribing prostitution, sodomy, perverted sexual practices, a bawdy place, adultery, fornication, any lewd and lascivious cohabitation, and all laws relating to obscene matter.

para.heading: Violations of City law.
para.text: No person conducting a massage establishment shall tolerate in his establishment any activity or behavior which violates this Code, particularly, but not exclusively, those sections which parallel the State statutes on immorality and obscenity detailed above.

para.heading: Penalties.
para.text: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as hereinafter provided in this subtitle and, in addition to such penalty, it shall be the duty of the Director of Finance to revoke the license of the establishment wherein the provisions of this section shall have been violated.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any massage establishment, its equipment, records, and methods of operation shall be open during working or business hours to inspection by representatives of the Police Department, Health Department, Fire Department, and the Department of Housing and Community Development.

para.heading: Regular inspections to be made; reports.
para.text: The Police Commissioner, Health Commissioner, Chief of the Fire Department, and the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development shall assign personnel to make regular inspection of such licenses, and a report of such inspections shall be made to the respective department heads in writing.

para.heading: Denial of entry cause for revocation.
para.text: Denial of entry of such inspectors during business hours shall be cause for revocation of the license.

para.heading: Grounds.
para.text: Whenever the Board believes that any licensed massage establishment or registered massagist has violated any of the provisions of this subtitle, the rules and regulations promulgated by the Board, or is not qualified to hold a license, it may order a hearing.

para.heading: Notice and hearing.
para.text: Such hearing shall be held at a reasonable time and place designated by the Board in written notice to the licensee. The hearing shall not be held until at least 10 days following actual receipt of notice by the licensee.

para.heading: Decision.
para.text: Following such hearing, the Board shall reduce findings of fact to writing, and if it determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this subtitle, the rules and regulations promulgated by the Board, or is unqualified under the provisions of this subtitle to hold the license in effect, it shall transmit a copy of such findings to the Director of Finance recommending revocation of the license, and the Director of Finance shall immediately revoke the license.

para.text: Any person violating any provision of this subtitle or failing to comply therewith is guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable upon conviction by a fine not to exceed $500 or imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment.
Each day that a violation continues is deemed to be a separate offense.

para.heading: License revocation.
para.text: Conviction for any violation of the provisions of this subtitle shall constitute cause for immediate revocation of the license by the Director of Finance upon the recommendation of the Board.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Commercial parking facility.
para.text: "Commercial parking facility" means any:
garage, structure, or part of a structure for the parking, storage, housing, or keeping of 3 or more motor vehicles in exchange for a fee or other consideration; or
parking lot or outdoor area or space for the parking, storage, housing, or keeping of 3 or more motor vehicles in exchange for a fee or other consideration.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

section.heading: Subtitle inapplicable to special-event parking.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to special-event parking lots operating under and in compliance with Subtitle 13 {"Special-Event Parking Lots"} of this article.

para.text: No person may operate a commercial parking facility in the City of Baltimore unless the person has first obtained an annual license for the facility and has paid the annual fee for the license.
The term of a license is from May 1 of each year through April 30 of the next year.

The annual fee for a commercial parking facility license is $5.10 for every 100 square feet (or fraction of 100 square feet) of the gross area used for parking facility purposes, including all parking spaces, offices, ramps, driveways, aisles, toilets, car washing, greasing, or other facilities used in connection with the operation of the parking facility.
For a license issued after July 31 and before November 1, the fee is 75% of that prescribed for the entire year.
For a license issued after October 31 and before February 1, the fee is 50% of that prescribed for the entire year.
For a license issued after January 31, the fee is 25% of that prescribed for the entire year.
Any person desiring to operate a commercial parking facility for an aggregate of no more than 6 months in any 1 license year may obtain a special partial-year license.
The fee for a partial-year license is 1/12 of the annual license fee for each month or fraction of a month that the parking facility is in operation.

para.heading: Online licensee list.
para.text: The Director of Finance shall maintain and post on the Department's website a current list of all commercial parking facilities licensed under this subtitle.

section.heading: Transfer of licenses.
section.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, a license issued under this subtitle is transferable during the license year.

section.heading: Tax arrearage bars renewal or transfer.
section.text: A license may not be issued to, renewed by, or transferred from or to any person from whom taxes, interest, or penalties are due and unpaid under City Code Article 28, Subtitle 22.

section.heading: Refund on acquisition, etc., by City.
section.text: If the City acquires title to or control of a commercial parking facility or terminates an existing lease covering any property used as a parking facility, and the owner, lessee, or operator of the commercial parking facility is thereby required to terminate the operation of the facility, then the owner, lessee, or operator is entitled to a refund of that portion of the license fee paid for the unexpired term of the license.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director of Finance may adopt rules and regulations for the administration and enforcement of this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: Except as specifically authorized in subsection (b) of this section, no person operating or employed by a commercial parking facility may store, park, or place a motor vehicle left for storage or parking on any street, alley, or highway in the City.

Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to the parking or placement of a vehicle on a street, alley, or highway if it is parked or placed there only for a sufficient time to permit the removal of another car from the commercial parking facility.
This exception does not apply between 7 a.m. and 10 a.m. or between 4 p.m. and 6 p.m.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: As a condition of licensure, a commercial parking facility must provide proof of payment to each customer of the facility at the time of payment.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: The proof of payment required by this section may be provided in either paper or electronic form.

section.heading: Removal of vehicles.
section.text: A commercial parking lot may not tow or contract with another person to tow a motor vehicle from a commercial parking lot without the motor vehicle's or authorized representative's authorization, unless the facility holds a valid license under § 12-4 {"License required; fee" of this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: After a hearing conducted in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle and with proper notice to the license holder, the Department of Finance may revoke a license if the Department finds that the license holder violated any provision of this subtitle.

para.heading: Form and effect of revocation.
para.text: Any revocation under this subtitle must be in writing from the Department of Finance and specify the reasons for the action.
A license holder aggrieved by a decision if the Department of Finance may appeal that decision to the Director of Finance in writing within 10 days of the Department's decision.
The Director of Finance must issue a written decision within 30 days of receipt of the license holder's appeal.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: Each vehicle towed a separate offense.
para.text: Each vehicle towed in violation of § 12-11 {"Removal of vehicles"} of this subtitle is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 6 months or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: Each vehicle towed a separate offense.
para.text: Each vehicle towed in violation of § 12-11 {"Removal of vehicles"} of this subtitle is a separate offense.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Director.
para.text: "Director" means the Director of the Department of Finance of his or her designee.

para.heading: Parking lot.
para.text: "Parking lot" means any outdoor area or space for the parking, storage, housing, or keeping of 3 or more motor vehicles in exchange for a fee or other consideration.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Person" has the meaning stated in § 1-107(a) {"Person: In general"} of the City Code's General Provisions Article.

para.heading: Inclusion of governmental entities.
para.text: Notwithstanding § 1-107(b) {"Person: Exclusion"} of the General Provisions Article, in this subtitle "person" also includes a governmental entity or an instrumentality or unit of a governmental entity.

para.heading: Special-event parking lot.
para.text: "Special-event parking lot" means a parking lot that:
is not otherwise licensed under Subtitle 12 {"Parking Facilities"} of this article;
is located within the Special-Event Parking District;
provides parking services to persons attending sporting, social, cultural, or other special events; and
operates:
only on days in which events are held at the Camden Yards Stadium Complex; and
for no more than 149 days in any license year.

section.heading: Rules, regulations, and forms.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Director may adopt rules, regulations, and forms to carry out this subtitle.

section.heading: License required.
section.text: No person may operate a special-event parking lot without having first obtained a license to do so from the Director.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The operator of the proposed special-event parking lot must apply to the Director for the special-event parking lot license.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: The application must be in the form that the Director requires.

section.heading: Applications – Required information.
section.text: The application must include:

para.text: the name, address, and telephone number of the parking lot's operator;
the name, address, and telephone number of the owner of the property on which the parking lot will operate;
the address of the proposed special-event parking lot;
the gross area of the parking lot, including all parking spaces, driveways, entrances, exits, aisles, and facilities used in connection with the operation of the parking lot;
the dates and times of the events for which the proposed parking lot will be in operation;
a schedule of parking fees to be charged;

evidence satisfactory to the Director that the operator has obtained liability insurance coverage in at least the amounts and tenor set by the Director in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle;
a traffic management plan that meets the requirements set in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle;
a security plan that meets the requirements set in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle;
a diagram of the property on which the proposed parking lot would be located, showing all parking spaces, driveways, entrances, exits, aisles, structures, and other facilities;
any other information that the Director requires; and
a signed affirmation, under penalties of perjury, that the applicant either:
is the owner of the property on which the parking lot will be operated; or
is authorized by the owner of the property to operate the parking lot.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Each special-event parking lot license expires annually on the anniversary of its issuance and is renewable as provided in this section.
To renew a special-event parking lot license, the licensee must apply no less than 30 days nor more than 90 days before the license expires.
The application must be in the form and contain the information that the Director requires.

section.heading: License fee.
section.text: The annual fee for a special-event parking lot license is as set by the Board of Estimates.

section.heading: Issuance of license.
section.text: On receipt of a license application and the applicable license fee, the Director shall:

para.text: review the application; and
issue the license if the following conditions are met:
the security plan included in the application ensures that vehicles parked in the parking lot are protected from theft and vandalism at all times during hours of operations;

the traffic management plan included in the application ensures that the flow of pedestrian and vehicular traffic in the surrounding area is not significantly impeded by the operation of the parking lot; and
the application is otherwise complete, in accordance with the requirements of this subtitle.

section.heading: Transfer.
section.text: A special-event parking lot license is not transferable to a new operator, to a different location, or otherwise.

section.heading: Tax arrearage bars issuance or renewal.
section.text: A license may not be issued to or renewed by any person from whom taxes, interest, or penalties are due and unpaid under City Code Article 28, Subtitle 22 {"Parking Tax"}.

para.heading: Required.
para.text: At all times while a special-event parking lot is in operation, an identification sign must be posted on each street frontage of the lot.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: Each identification sign must contain:
the name, address, and telephone number of the lot's operator;
the license number of the operator's special-event parking lot license; and
the fee charged for parking.

para.heading: Limitations.
para.text: No sign may:
exceed 12 square feet;
be more than 24 feet high;
project more than 3 feet across a street line;
be illuminated; or
remain on the property for longer than 2 hours after the end of the event for which the lot was open.

section.heading: Attendant on duty.
section.text: An adult attendant must be present at all times while any vehicle remains parked on a special-event parking lot.

para.heading: Prohibited conduct.
para.text: Except as specifically authorized in subsection (b) of this section, no person operating or employed by a special-event parking lot may park or place a motor vehicle left for parking on any street, alley, or highway in the City.

Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to the parking or placement of a vehicle on a street, alley, or highway if it is parked or placed there only for a sufficient time to permit the removal of another car from the parking lot.
This exception does not apply between 7 a.m. and 10 a.m. or between 4 p.m. and 6 p.m.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of an environmental citation under City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}.

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $1,000 or imprisonment for not more than 6 months or both fine and imprisonment for each offense.

para.heading: Each day a separate offense.
para.text: Each day that a violation continues is a separate offense.

para.heading: In General.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meaning indicated.

para.heading: Board.
para.text: "Board" means the Board of Licenses for Street Entertainers.

para.heading: Street.
para.text: "Street" means any street, boulevard, road, highway, alley, lane, sidewalk, footway, mall, esplanade, or other way or place that is owned by the City or habitually used by the public.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Street entertainer" means any person who, either alone or as part of a group:
performs on the streets of this City; and
solicits, encourages, or accepts donations before, during, or after the performance.

para.heading: Illustrations.
para.text: "Street entertainer" includes a:
musician;
juggler;
mime;
puppeteer;
unicyclist;
clown;
magician
sword swallower;
dancer;
poet;
performance artist; or
comedian.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide standard definition of “person”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-107.
For the Code-wide standard definition of “includes” and “including”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-105.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: There is a Board of Licenses for Street Entertainers.

para.heading: Composition.
para.text: The Board comprises the following 7 members:
4 members appointed by the Mayor in accordance with City Charter Article IV, §6; and
2 members appointed by the President of the City Council; and
the Director of the Community Relations Commission or the Director's designee.

para.heading: Officers.
para.text: The Board annually shall;
elect a Chair from among its members; and
appoint a Secretary.

para.heading: Compensation; expenses.
para.text: The members of the Board:
serve without compensation; but
are entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses incurred in the performance of their duties, as provided in the Ordinance of Estimates.

section.heading: Staff.
section.text: The Board may appoint employees, assistants, and investigators as provided in the Ordinances of Estimates.

section.heading: Rules and regulations.
section.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Board shall adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

annotations.annotation: By authority of Ordinance 20-431, Section 5, the Director of Legislative Reference, in consultation with the Law Department, has conformed this section to refer expressly to and reflect the requirements of the recently-enacted Administrative Procedure Act that, effective January 15, 2021, governs the proposal, adoption, and publication of administrative rules and regulations.

section.heading: License required.
section.text: No person may perform as a street entertainer without first having obtained a license to do so from the Board of Licenses for Street Entertainers.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In its rules and regulations, the Board shall:
designate various classes of licenses to be issued; and
for each class of license, specify:
the types of entertainment that may be performed under the license;
the locations or areas for which the license is effective;
the days and times for which the license is effective; and
the maximum number of licenses to be issued for a particular location or area or for a particular day or time of day.

para.heading: Required considerations.
para.text: In designating classes and specifying limitations, the Board shall consider:
the volume and types of vehicular and pedestrian traffic in a proposed street entertainment location or area;
the proximity of schools, religious institutions, parks, or residencies to a proposed street entertainment location or area;
the number of licenses issued to the same person; and
the impact of street entertainment activities on the health, safety, and general welfare of the public.

section.heading: Limitations and conditions.
section.text: The Board may impose reasonable limitations on any license issued under this subtitle, as necessary or proper to carry out the purpose and intent of this subtitle.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: An application for a license must be made in the form the Board requires.

para.heading: Application fee.
para.text: The application must be accompanied by a one-time, non-refundable application fee of $25, to cover the cost of investigating and processing the application.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The application must contain:
the applicant's name and address;
the applicant's age;
the type of entertainment for which the license is sought;
the location or area for which the license is sought; and
any other information the Board requires.

para.heading: Verification.
para.text: The application must be verified before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Unless renewed, a license expires on the 1st anniversary of its effective date.

para.heading: Renewal.
para.text: Before a license expires, a licensee may renew it for an additional 1-year term, if the licensee submits to the Board a renewal application in the form the Board requires.
Except as specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection, no fee may be imposed for the timely renewal of a license.

If a licensee seeks to modify the terms of her or his license (e.g., location or type of entertainment), the renewal application must be accompanied by a one-time, non-refundable application fee of $25.

para.heading: Board to issue.
para.text: The Board shall issue an identification badge for each license issued.

para.heading: Form and contents.
para.text: The identification badge:
shall be of laminated plastic or other durable substance; and
shall bear:
the name and address of the licensee;
the type of entertainment for which the license is issued;
the location or area for which the license is issued;
the days or times to which the license is limited;
the year for which the license is issued; and
an identifying number that corresponds with the number of the license.

para.heading: Entertainer to display.
para.text: Each entertainer must prominently display the badge while entertaining.

para.heading: Replacement badges.
para.text: If a badge is lost, the Board shall issue a replacement badge on payment by the licensee of a $10 fee.

section.heading: BOPA to assist.
section.text: The Baltimore Office of Promotion and The Arts shall assist the Board by:

para.text: advertising and promoting the availability of licenses under this subtitle; and
distributing to licensees the licenses and badges issued under this subtitle.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct.
section.text: A street entertainer may not:

para.text: set any fee or require any donation for his or her performance; or
suggest any minimum or maximum donation.

para.heading: Authorized suspension or revocation.
para.text: The Board may suspend or revoke a license if the licensee violates any provision of:
this subtitle;
the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle; or
any other applicable law of the State or City.

para.heading: Mandatory revocation.
para.text: On a street entertainer's 3rd violation of any provision, the Board must revoke the street entertainer's license.

para.heading: Application following revocation.
para.text: If a license is revoked, the former licensee may not apply for a new license until 1 year from the date of revocation.

para.heading: Right of appeal.
para.text: An aggrieved party may appeal to the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals:
the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license; or
any other decision or ruling by the Board of Licenses.

para.heading: How and when taken.
para.text: The appeal must be taken in writing within 10 days from the date of notice of the denial, suspension, revocation, decision, or ruling.

para.heading: Hearing and decision.
para.text: The Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals:
shall hold a hearing on the appeal as soon as practicable; and
may affirm, modify, or reverse the action of the Board of Licenses.

section.heading: Penalties.
section.text: Any person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of the rules and regulations adopted under it is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a fine of not more than $500 for each offense.

annotations.annotation: Ordinance 14-237 substantially rewrote this subtitle, transferring the powers of the former “Board of Licenses for Street Vendors” to the Department of General Services and, among other things, establishing special regulatory provisions for mobile vendors. Pursuant to Section 4 of Ord. 14-237, the new subtitle becomes effective on February 28, 2015, that being the 30th day after the Department of General Services filed its rules and regulations for this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.

para.heading: Department.
para.text: "Department" means the Baltimore City Department of Transportation.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Food product" means any item used as food, drink, confectionery, or condiment for human consumption, whether simple or compound.

para.heading: Exclusions.
para.text: "Food product" does not include medicine, drugs, or alcohol.

para.heading: Ice cream truck.
para.text: "Ice cream truck" means a vendor that earns substantially all of its revenue from the sale of ice cream or similar frozen food confections from a vehicle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: "Mobile vendor" means any person that sells, distributes, or offers to sell or distribute food products, other merchandise of any kind, or services from a motor vehicle on City streets or private property within the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Exclusion.
para.text: "Mobile vendor" does not include a horse-drawn wagon.

para.heading: Mobile vending zone.
para.text: "Mobile vending zone" means an area designated in accordance with § 17-5 {"Mobile vending zones"} of this subtitle for the use of mobile vendors.

para.heading: Motor vehicle.
para.text: "Motor vehicle" has the meaning stated in Article 31, §1-2(c){"Motor vehicle"}.

para.heading: Street.
para.text: "Street" means any street, boulevard, road, highway, alley, lane, sidewalk, footway, mall, esplanade, or other way or place that is owned by the City or habitually used by the public.

para.heading: Street vendor.
para.text: "Street vendor" means:
a mobile vendor; or
any other person who sells or distributes, or offers to sell or distribute food products or other merchandise on any street.

para.heading: Vendor truck.
para.text: "Vendor truck" means any motor vehicle used for the purpose of selling any food product, other merchandise, or service by a mobile vendor.

para.heading: Vendor vehicle.
para.text: "Vendor vehicle" means:
any animal-drawn wagon;
any motor vehicle; or
any trailer, handcart, pushcart, or other vehicle.

annotations.annotation: For the Code-wide standard definition of “person”, see City General Provisions Article, § 1-107.

For the Code-wide standard uses of mandatory terms (“must” and “shall”), prohibitory terms (“may not”, “must not”, and “no ... may”), and permissive terms (“may”), see City General Provisions Article, § 1-104.

para.heading: Department may adopt.
para.text: Subject to Title 4 {"Administrative Procedure Act – Regulations"} of the City General Provisions Article, the Department of Transportation may adopt rules and regulations to carry out this subtitle.

para.heading: Public hearing and comment.
para.text: In accordance with General Provisions Article § 4-301, the Department of Transportation must publish, for public hearing and comment, notice of all rules and regulations proposed for adoption under this subtitle.

para.heading: Effective date.
para.text: A copy of all rules and regulations under this subtitle must be filed with the Department of Legislative Reference at least 30 days before they take effect.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: After public notice has been provided to area business and neighborhood organizations, the Director of Transportation may designate spaces on City streets or other public property as "mobile vending zones" for the exclusive use of mobile vendors during designated hours.

para.heading: Required considerations.
para.text: A proposed designation under paragraph (1) of this subsection must contain an assessment of the zone's potential impact on:
vehicular and pedestrian traffic, including any impediment to ingress to and egress from established businesses;
public safety and health;
parking in the area; and
area residents and businesses.

para.heading: Restriction on zones near schools.
para.text: No mobile vending zone may be designated within 2 blocks of the grounds of any building used as a public or private kindergarten, elementary school, or secondary school.

para.heading: Time-limited zones.
para.text: The mobile vending zones designated under this section may be set aside for the use of mobile vendors at all times or for specified times, dates, and days.

para.heading: Temporary relocation or suspension.
para.text: The Department of Transportation may temporarily relocate or suspend mobile vending zones at any time due to emergencies or to further public safety, public health interests, or City operations.

para.heading: Signage.
para.text: Mobile vending zones designated under this section must be marked by clear signs that specify the hours and times during which the zones are reserved for the exclusive use of mobile vendors.

para.heading: Rules and regulations.
para.text: The rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle must:
establish a process and timeline for requesting, establishing, assigning, and removing mobile vending zones; and
require a public hearing, as well as provide an opportunity for the filing of written protests, before a mobile vending zone is designated.

section.heading: Newspaper sales excepted from subtitle.
section.text: This subtitle does not apply to the sale of newspapers.

section.heading: License required.
section.text: No street vendor may operate in Baltimore City without first having obtained a license to do so from the Department of Transportation.

annotation.doc: City of Balt., Md., Ord. 99-526 Ord. 04-854

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In its rules and regulations, the Department may:
designate various classes of licenses to be issued; and
for each class of license, specify:
the types of merchandise that may be sold under the license;
the locations or areas for which the license is effective;
the days and times for which the license is effective;
the maximum number of licenses to be issued for a particular location or area or for a particular day or time of day;
the maximum number of licenses of each class that may be issued in total; and
the maximum number of licenses that may be issued to a single person.

para.heading: Required considerations.
para.text: In designating classes and specifying limitations, the Department must consider:
the volume and types of vehicular and pedestrian traffic in a proposed vending location or area;
the proximity to a proposed vending location or area of schools, religious institutions, parks, and residences;
the number of licenses issued to the same person;
the impact of street vending activities on the health, safety, and general welfare of the public; and
comments from area schools, businesses, institutions, and residents.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Department of Transportation may impose reasonable limitations and conditions on any license issued under this subtitle, as necessary or proper to carry out the purpose and intent of this subtitle.

Except as otherwise provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Department may determine the size, shape, design, and dimensions of any container, conveyance, sign, table, chair, other appurtenance, or vendor vehicle to be used in connection with a license issued under this subtitle.

The Department may not issue a new or renewal license for a mobile vendor to operate out of any vehicle with a total operating space that is longer than 25 feet, including any generator, hitch, trailer, or other motor vehicle attachment.

annotation.text: Section 3 of Ordinance 14-237 qualifies this subsection as follows

[N]otwithstanding Article 15, § 17-17(b)(2), as enacted by this Ordinance, a mobile vendor who, on the effective date of this Ordinance, held a valid street vendor’s license for a vehicle longer than 25 feet is entitled, if otherwise qualified for a license and renewals under this Ordinance, to obtain a license and 1 or more consecutive renewals for the continued operation of that vehicle for up to, but not beyond, 5 years after the effective date of this Ordinance.

para.heading: Form.
para.text: An application for a license must be made in the form that the Department of Transportation requires.

para.heading: Contents.
para.text: The application must contain:
the applicant's name and address;
the applicant's age;
the type of merchandise or service for which the license is sought;
the location or area for which the license is sought;
for the sale of any food product, evidence that the applicant has obtained the appropriate license from the Health Department; and
any other information that the Department of Transportation requires.
The application must be signed and verified before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths.

If the application is by a sole proprietorship, it must be signed by the owner; if by a partnership, it must be signed by an authorized partner; or, if by a corporation, limited liability company, or similar entity, it must be signed by an authorized officer.

para.heading: Term.
para.text: Except as provided in § 17-20 {"Temporary Licenses"} of this subtitle, a license expires on the 1st anniversary of its effective date.
Before a license expires, the street vendor may renew it for an additional 1-year term.
A renewal application must be:
in the form the Department of Transportation requires; and
submitted to the Department, with the applicable annual fee, at least 30 days before the current license expires.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The Department of Transportation may issue a temporary license to be used in connection with a charitable, educational, artistic, civic, or other public function or activity.
The term of a temporary license is 4 days.
A temporary license may be renewed for 1 additional 4-day period on application and payment of an additional license fee for that renewal period.

Further renewal periods beyond the 1 authorized by paragraph (2) of this subsection require the approval of the Department after consultation with affected businesses, residents, and community organizations.

para.heading: Board of Estimates to set fees.
para.text: Application, license, and other fees are as set by the Board of Estimates from time to time.

para.heading: Varying fees.
para.text: The fees established by the Board of Estimates may vary based on the license class, vendor type, or location at which a vendor is authorized to operate.

section.heading: Department to maintain list of licenses.
section.text: The Department must maintain a list of all current licenses issued under this subtitle.

para.heading: Scope of section.
para.text: This section does not apply to a person who obtains a country grower's license under§ 17-25 {"Vendor identification – Country growers"} of this subtitle.

para.heading: Department to issue.
para.text: The Department of Transportation must issue an identification badge for each license issued.

para.heading: Form and contents.
para.text: The identification badge:
must be of laminated plastic or other durable substance; and
must bear:
the street vendor's name and address;
the type of merchandise or service for which the license is issued;
the location or area for which the license is issued;
the days or times to which the license is limited;
the date on which the license expires; and
an identifying number that corresponds with number of the license.

para.heading: Vendor to display.
para.text: While vending, each street vendor must prominently display the badge in the manner specified in the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Replacement badges.
para.text: If a badge is lost, the Department must issue a replacement badge on payment by the licensee of the applicable fee.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A street vendor who sells fruits, vegetables, or other perishable articles that have been produced or grown by that vendor may apply for a special, country grower's license under this section.

para.heading: Application.
para.text: The application for a country grower's license must contain, in addition to the information required by § 17-18 {"Applications"} of this subtitle:
the location of the land from which the fruits, vegetables, and other perishable articles are produced or grown;
whether the applicant owns or leases that land and, if the latter, the name of the owner and the term of the lease; and
a statement that the applicant:
intends to use the license personally or by agent solely for the sale of his or her own produce; and
will not permit the license or the sign issued under this section to be used by any other person or for the sale of any produce other than that which he or she produces or grows.

Instead of the badge provided for in § 17-24 {"Vendor identification – In general"} of this subtitle, the Department of Transportation must provide the producer or grower with a sign to be displayed on his or her vehicle.
This sign must be:
of the size and design the Department determines; and
imprinted with:
the words "Country Grower's License No. "; and
the date the license expires.
The producer or grower must display this sign in a conspicuous place on his or her vendor vehicle.

para.heading: Receptacles required.
para.text: Every street vendor of food products must provide sufficient trash receptacles for the use of customers.

para.heading: Trash removal.
para.text: On leaving any location, the street vendor must remove all trash within a 10-foot radius of the place at which the vendor vehicle stood or was parked.

section.heading: Mobile vendors – Near mobile vending zones.
section.text: A mobile vendor may not park a vendor truck within 2 blocks of a mobile vending zone.

section.heading: Mobile vendors – Near retail store.
section.text: A mobile vendor may not park a vendor truck within 300 feet of any retail business establishment that is primarily engaged in selling the same type of food product, other merchandise, or service as that offered by the mobile vendor.

section.heading: Mobile food vendors – Operating without logbook.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: A mobile vendor may not sell any food product without keeping a detailed logbook noting the vendor's daily use of its supporting commissary.

para.heading: Form of logbook.
para.text: The logbook must:
be in the form the Department of Transportation requires; and
contain all the information required by the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: Logbook to be available for inspection.
para.text: The logbook must be made available for review to any City inspector or enforcement officer upon request.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In a residential area, no street vendor may stand or park his or her vehicle:
for more than 15 minutes at a given location, except as authorized by subsection (b) of this section; or
within 300 feet of any location at which the vehicle stood or parked during the preceding 48 hours.

para.heading: Exception for ice cream trucks with customers.
para.text: An ice cream truck may not stand or park at a given location for more than 15 minutes unless necessary to serve immediate customers.

section.heading: All vendors – Between midnight and 6 a.m.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a street vendor may not operate between the hours of midnight and 6 a.m.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a street vendor operating between the hours of midnight and 6 a.m. in accordance with the terms and conditions of a special event permit from the Department of Transportation that explicitly grants permission to operate during those hours.

section.heading: All vendors – Near City market.
section.text: No street vendor may operate within 2 blocks of a City market designated in City Code Article 16, § 1-2 {"Scope of article"}.

section.heading: All vendors – Near school or school transit stop.
section.text: From 7 a.m. to 8 p.m., no street vendor may stand or park her or his vendor vehicle within 2 blocks of the grounds of:

para.text: any building used as a public or private kindergarten, elementary school, or secondary school; or
any public transit stop serving a kindergarten, elementary school, or secondary school.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a street vendor may not sell any food product, other merchandise, or service within 2 blocks of the perimeter of any farmers' market authorized by the Commissioner of Housing and Community Development when the farmers' market is in operation.

para.heading: Exception.
para.text: Subsection (a) of this section does not apply to a street vendor who:
has written permission from the farmers' market organizer and permit holder to operate as a participating vendor of the farmers' market; and
prominently displays documentation evidencing this permission issued in accordance with the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: In addition to any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement procedure, this subtitle may be enforced by issuance of:
an environmental citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 40 {"Environmental Control Board"}; or
a civil citation as authorized by City Code Article 1, Subtitle 41 {"Civil Citations"}

para.heading: Process not exclusive.
para.text: The issuance of a citation to enforce this subtitle does not preclude pursuing any other civil or criminal remedy or enforcement action authorized by law.

section.heading: Criminal penalties.
section.text: A person who violates any provision of this subtitle or of a rule or regulation adopted under this subtitle is guilty of a misdemeanor and, on conviction, is subject to a penalty of $500 for each offense.

para.heading: Authorized suspension or revocation.
para.text: The Department of Transportation may suspend or revoke a license if the licensee violates any provision of:
this subtitle;
the rules and regulations adopted under this subtitle; or
any other applicable law of the State or City.

para.heading: Mandatory revocation.
para.text: On a street vendor's 3rd violation of any provision of Part III of this subtitle within any 1-year period, the Department must revoke that street vendor's license.

para.heading: Application following revocation.
para.text: If a license is revoked, the former licensee may not apply for a new license until at least 1 year from the date of revocation.

para.heading: Stay of operations.
para.text: The Department's issuance of a denial, suspension, or revocation of a license is effective immediately, and any operations previously allowed by the denied, suspended, or revoked license must cease immediately and may not resume until the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals issues a written decision reversing the Department's decision.

para.heading: Right of appeal.
para.text: An aggrieved party may appeal to the Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals:
the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license; or
any other decision or ruling by the the Department of Transportation relating to the administration of this subtitle.

para.heading: How and when taken.
para.text: The appeal must be taken in writing within 10 days from the date of notice of the denial, suspension, revocation, decision, or ruling.

para.heading: Hearing and decision.
para.text: The Board of Municipal and Zoning Appeals:
must hold a hearing on the appeal as soon as practicable; and
may affirm, modify, or reverse the action of the Department.

para.heading: Established place of business.
para.text: The term "established place of business", as used in this subtitle, shall mean and include any building or room licensed for the handling of the products in this subtitle named.

para.heading: Itinerant wholesale produce dealer.
para.text: The term "itinerant wholesale produce dealer", for the purposes of this subtitle, shall mean and include any person, firm, association, or corporation who is a non-resident of the City of Baltimore and/or the State of Maryland and who is without an established place of business within the City of Baltimore, selling or offering for sale from any cart, wagon, truck, automobile, or other vehicle any fruits, vegetables, garden produce, butter, eggs, cheese, game, veal, pork, mutton, lamb, rabbits, or poultry not grown, raised, produced, made, manufactured, caught, trapped, or killed in the State of Maryland to any person, firm, or corporation for the purpose of resale, or to any restaurant, hotel, or public institution within the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Established business in City.
para.text: Provided, however, that this subtitle shall not apply to or affect any dealer having an established place of business within the City of Baltimore.

para.heading: Duly accredited establishments.
para.text: Nor shall it apply to or affect any person, firm, or corporation who sells exclusively to or through, or who buys exclusively from, a duly accredited wholesale food establishment that is licensed and complies with the requirements, as such, of the City of Baltimore, and State of Maryland.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Provided further, that this subtitle shall not apply to a farmer or producer or person who offers for sale or sells to retailers, hotels, restaurants, processors, or public institutions or to commission merchants the products herein mentioned, or any of them, which were grown, raised, or produced, made, manufactured, caught, trapped, or killed, within the State of Maryland.

para.heading: Permit required.
para.text: But it shall be unlawful, however, for any such farmer or producer or person or any employees of such farmer or producer, or person to engage in the business of selling the products herein mentioned, or any of them, to retailers, hotels, restaurants, or public institutions within the City of Baltimore unless he applies annually to the Director of Finance for a permit so to sell.

Any farmer or producer or person desiring to secure such permit shall file with the Director of Finance annually an application, with his post office address, subscribed and sworn to before a notary public, which shall state that he will sell or offer for sale only such products as were grown, raised, produced, made, manufactured, caught, trapped, or killed in the State of Maryland.
It shall be the duty of the said Director of Finance to investigate and verify the statements of the applicant if he is not satisfied with the proofs submitted.
The permits issued to farmers or producers or persons shall be in the form of a metal plate, on which shall be printed or stamped "Farmer's Permit No. ".
The fee for such permit shall not exceed $1 each.

para.heading: Display.
para.text: Said plate shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on wagon or other vehicle by said farmer or producer or person at all times when selling his products.

section.heading: License required for itinerant dealers.
section.text: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, association, or corporation to conduct or operate the business of an itinerant wholesale produce dealer, as hereinbefore in this subtitle defined, without first having obtained a license so to do.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: Written application therefor shall be made to the Director of Finance on forms prepared by him.
Such application shall contain:
the name and address of the applicant;
if the applicant is a firm, the name and address of each member of the firm; and
if the applicant is a corporation or association, the names and addresses of its principal officers.

The application shall contain such further information as may be required by the Director of Finance in order to inform him fully as to the nature of the business, the equipment and facilities to be used.

para.heading: License fee.
para.text: The license fee for each and every cart, wagon, truck, automobile, or other vehicle used in the business of an itinerant wholesale produce dealer and operated or propelled along or upon the streets or thoroughfares of the City of Baltimore shall be $200 per annum, or a portion thereof, for each vehicle, which amount shall be paid to the Director of Finance.

para.heading: Term; nontransferable.
para.text: Said license:
shall expire on January 1 of each year; and
shall not be transferable.

para.heading: In general.
para.text: The following regulations and conditions shall be observed by itinerant wholesale produce dealers licensed under this subtitle.

Each such dealer shall have his name, address, and the number of his license painted conspicuously on both sides of his, its, or her cart or carts, wagon or wagons, truck or trucks, automobile or automobiles, or other vehicles in letters and figures of not less than 2 inches in height, or have the same printed or stamped on metal plates to be so displayed on both sides of said vehicles.

And he or she or it shall also carry such license and shall exhibit the same whenever required by any police officer or other officer authorized under the laws or ordinances of the City of Baltimore to make arrests.

para.heading: Compliance with laws.
para.text: In addition to the conditions and regulations above set forth, each itinerant wholesale produce dealer licensed under this subtitle shall be subject to the laws of Maryland and the ordinances of Baltimore City governing the sale of food products.

section.heading: Revocation of license.
section.text: The Mayor may revoke such license at any time by notice in writing whenever it shall appear to his satisfaction that the licensee has violated the provisions of this subtitle and has failed to correct same upon due notice from the Director of Finance.
